text: Well, the armed forces did so much to, you know, Agent Orange,

speaker: A
text: they did so much to their own people all during that time.

speaker: A
text: You know, and they they take a, even now, uh, they take a free hand as far as medicine and, uh, you know, how they treat the war casualties, you know.

speaker: A
text: If you come back and your leg is blown off, you know, or, or it is hanging by a thread, they still can't put it back together now.

speaker: A
text: But, But what they do afterwards and how they rehabilitate you.

speaker: B
text: Well, you know, one of the most troublesome things that I have encountered as a result is the incredible influx of southeast Asians into this country since that conflict.

speaker: B
text: Uh, not so, much that I say, I do not want you here.

speaker: B
text: But there is just such a surge of southeast Asians.

speaker: B
text: It has affected the culture of this country, uh, very much.

speaker: A
text: It's it's about nine or ten percent now.

speaker: B
text: Well, uh, the culture is changing.

speaker: B
text: Look how much more Oriental food we have, restaurants now, for example.

speaker: B
text: Uh, even ten years ago, there were not that many.

speaker: B
text: A lot of shops are, are operated by southeast Asians.

speaker: B
text: A lot of people have complained in the schools.

speaker: B
text: There is a culture change there.

speaker: B
text: The southeast Asians seem to be very hungry,

speaker: B
text: there seem to be very studious.

speaker: B
text: And, uh, tends to cause our kids to really have to buckle down to keep up with them, which is not bad.

speaker: B
text: Uh, but it might in the long run you can see where scholarships, for example, uh, even jobs. Uh, jobs that would normally go to an American, with a lesser education, might be going to, to some of these people here.

speaker: B
text: And that is all a result of, of, of Vietnam.

speaker: B
text: And, and you see a lot of, a lot of men that were over there, brought families back.

speaker: B
text: Uh, and it concerns me that there is probably a lot of mixed breed youngsters still there.

speaker: B
text: And I would be concerned or interested to find out how they are doing now.

text: Well, they are probably not doing very well at all.

text: Because I know there is, there is still people even in the Dallas area.

speaker: A
text: There are, there are still people trying to get some member of their family back from, uh, Vietnam.

text: You are talking about P O W or missing in actions?

text: They were lost, you know, when they were little,

speaker: A
text: and, and they never did get back

text: That, that had not occurred to me.

speaker: B
text: That would be an interesting concept.

text: And, uh, and, as is really a big waste because they didn't, they didn't win,

speaker: A
text: they didn't regain any of the land that they had.

speaker: A
text: It spilled over into, uh, now I can't even think of the country.

speaker: A
text: and, and all they did is run and hide.

speaker: A
text: And they were not really fighting, you know,

speaker: A
text: it, it would have been the same as Desert Storm if all they had been fighting was North Vietnam.

speaker: A
text: But, and I am not even sure who was involved more. Whether it was China or Russia.

speaker: A
text: You know, they were pouring, they were pouring weapons in there and, and advising, well, digging tunnels for them. You know,

speaker: A
text: and there is no way that they could ever catch them.

text: Well, I think the terrain had a lot to do with the, the success of Desert Storm as opposed to that in Vietnam.

speaker: B
text: You know, there is incredible cover in Vietnam.

speaker: B
text: And you can't find much cover on, in a sand dune

speaker: A
text: all they can do is dig in,

speaker: A
text: and then they try to camouflage the top.

speaker: A
text: Well now, even, I think even now, and in Vietnam they could probably have done a better job.

speaker: A
text: Because they could, they could kill all those plants, you know, which would devastate the country as far as farming from then on.

speaker: A
text: But, and the, and the Corps of Engineers I think do a better job now, like they did in Desert Storm.

speaker: A
text: he, he dug a bunch of moats and filled them with oil

speaker: A
text: and he set a lot of booby traps all along the way as they went.

speaker: A
text: And they had to, you know, they had to blow them up or, or disarm them.

speaker: A
text: And then they had to fill in little bridges all the way where he, where he had made those moats.

text: What world war do you think they found the experience for that?

speaker: B
text: Don't you think they learned from the mistakes in Vietnam?

speaker: B
text: Part of it is that, part of it is technology.

speaker: A
text: Part of it is technology, yeah.

speaker: B
text: But when, when, When you get into trouble like that in a place like Vietnam, you do tend to analyze the problems that you get into,

speaker: B
text: And, and you overcome those problems,

speaker: B
text: and you are prepared next time.

text: I think that is one of the reasons that they have, they have pretty much avoided getting involved in South America.

speaker: A

speaker: A

text: Well, I know that, uh, from a personal standpoint, people was one of the finest assets that we lost.

speaker: B
text: We did not actually physically lose them.

speaker: B
text: They did not lose their lives,

speaker: B
text: but they lost a whole lot of the life they might have had.

speaker: B
text: I had dinner Monday night with a Vietnam veteran who is just now beginning to recover from the drug and alcohol struggle that he had.

speaker: B
text: That is a long time to suffer.

speaker: A
text: everybody that has, that has stood there,

speaker: A
text: in Vietnam I think it was much closer contact.

speaker: A
text: You stand there with a rifle and blow a, a piece of somebody apart, or blow their head off,

speaker: A
text: and that has to affect you if you are human, you know.

speaker: A
text: So they had to work all that, that anger out, and the, and the nightmares that come along with it.

speaker: A
text: I do not, I do not really think that anybody can ever forget that,

speaker: A
text: but they can, they can reason and, and try to adjust to, to why they were there.

speaker: B
text: Well, you see that is what the veterans are so angry about now.

speaker: B
text: They say, "Well, we're, going to listen to this and we are going to look at this, find out what our mistakes were, and we are not going to make them again."

speaker: B
text: But that does not undo the ones that were done.

speaker: B
text: And that is what makes the veterans angry.

speaker: B
text: I do not know a solution.

speaker: B
text: But I sure cannot blame them for being angry.

speaker: B
text: On the other hand, you know, you can be angry about something for a very long time,

speaker: B
text: or you can say, "Well, that is the way it is," and go on with your life.

speaker: B
text: For the most part, I wish that it had not happened.

speaker: A

speaker: A
text: And he just, he did not want to be in it any more than, than what we started out in August with Desert Storm.

speaker: A
text: And then it just blew up into the war.

speaker: B
text: Well, it has been that way for a very, very long time, though.

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B

text: I think they're in some instances they're, they're over used,

speaker: B
text: like every body has their own P C which a lot of times everybody doesn't need a P C,

speaker: B
text: without them knowing how to use it properly, it slows them down, more than it helps them accomplish something.

speaker: B
text: They spend more time messing with the P C than they would actually accomplishing the tasks that they're trying to do if they didn't have a P C at all.

text: And you really have to be able to type pretty fast before, you know, before it really saves time.

speaker: B
text: And you have to, you know, be familiar with it,

speaker: B
text: like there're so many different software packages, it, you have to be familiar with the one that you're going to be using most.

speaker: B
text: A lot of times, uh, people know about half of the capabilities of a package that they should know to actually be able to use it properly,

speaker: B
text: and so they waste more time with their trying to, uh, figure out how to do, you know, other things, than they would if they, if they actually understood what they were trying to do.

speaker: B
text: You know, like, uh, they want to, to format a report a certain way

speaker: B
text: and if they really understood the capabilities of the package they could, they could do that in about, you know, half the time that they spend trying to figure out how to do it without spending the time to learn the package properly.

speaker: A
text: To set up the boundaries correctly, and how many lines you're going to use in an,

speaker: B
text: A lot of times they, they, they do it manually on the computer, which just really is a waste of time,

speaker: B
text: and then, if they ever have to change anything in that, in that, in the document, they have to go back and redo it all manually, whereas if they had learned the package properly to start with and had set it up correctly, the package would do that for them whenever they wanted to make a change,

speaker: A
text: Can't you, can't you put, Can't you put it on a disk and then just edit it, if you need to when you go back.

speaker: B
text: so I, I've seen that as a problem.

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B
text: And they set it up manually, so that they have all their spacings and formattings and tabs set manually.

speaker: B
text: And, um, then when they have to make a change, say they want to insert a paragraph. They got to go through the document and reset all the page breaks manually and rewrite the whole thing instead of having the,

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B
text: So, you see, like in a newspaper, they typeset.

speaker: B
text: If the, if one line is going to be a lot shorter than another line, they just add spaces to that line to make it look long as the rest of the lines.

text: They space it out in, in the line itself.

text: Most most software packages will do that for you.

speaker: B

speaker: B
